user_queries: How do I perform CPR on an adult?
An adult collapsed and isn't breathing
Help, a man is down and not breathing!
What do I do for cardiac arrest in an adult?
how to do chest compressions on an adult
someone passed out and isn't breathing

response.immediate_action: Call 911 or instruct someone else to call. Get an AED if available.
response.context: This is for an unresponsive adult who is not breathing normally. Ensure the environment is safe before approaching.

steps.instruction: Place the heel of one hand on the center of the chest, on the breastbone. Place the other hand on top and interlock your fingers.
Position yourself vertically above the chest. With straight arms, push down hardâ€”2 to 2.4 inches (5-6 cm) deep.
Push at a rate of 100 to 120 compressions per minute. Allow the chest to recoil completely after each compression.
Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 rescue breaths if you are trained. Otherwise, perform hands-only CPR.

response.additional_notes: Continue CPR until help arrives, an AED is ready to use, or the person starts breathing normally. Minimize interruptions in chest compressions.

warnings: Only perform CPR on someone who is unresponsive and not breathing.
Ensure an ambulance is on the way.
If you are untrained, provide hands-only CPR (chest compressions only).

user_queries: How do I perform CPR on a child?

response.immediate_action: If you are alone, perform 2 minutes of CPR first, then call 911. If another person is available, have them call 911 immediately.
response.context: This is for an unresponsive child (from age 1 to puberty) who is not breathing normally.

steps.instruction: Place the heel of one or two hands on the center of the chest (depending on the child's size).
Push down about 2 inches (5 cm) deep at a rate of 100 to 120 compressions per minute.
After 30 compressions, give 2 gentle rescue breaths if trained. Ensure the chest rises with each breath.

response.additional_notes: Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths until help arrives or the child responds.

warnings: For infants (under 1 year), use infant CPR techniques.
Be gentler than with an adult but ensure compressions are effective.

user_queries: How do I perform CPR on a baby?

response.immediate_action: If you are alone, perform 2 minutes of CPR first, then call 911. If another person is available, have them call 911 immediately.
response.context: This is for an unresponsive infant (under 1 year old) who is not breathing normally.

steps.instruction: Place two fingers on the center of the chest, just below the nipple line.
Push down about 1.5 inches (4 cm) deep at a rate of 100 to 120 compressions per minute.
After 30 compressions, give 2 gentle puffs of air (rescue breaths) if trained. Cover the infant's nose and mouth with your mouth.

response.additional_notes: Continue cycles of 30 compressions and 2 breaths until help arrives or the infant responds.

warnings: Do not tilt the infant's head back too far.
Be extremely gentle with compressions and breaths.

user_queries: How do I help a choking adult?

response.immediate_action: Ask the person: 'Are you choking?' If they cannot speak, cough, or breathe, begin help immediately.

steps.instruction: Stand behind the person and wrap your arms around their waist.
Make a fist with one hand. Place the thumb side of your fist against the person's abdomen, just above the navel but below the ribcage.
Grasp your fist with your other hand and perform quick, upward thrusts into the abdomen.
Continue thrusts until the object is dislodged or the person becomes unconscious.

response.additional_notes: If the person becomes unconscious, lower them to the ground and begin CPR.

warnings: Do not perform abdominal thrusts on a person who is coughing forcefully or able to speak.

user_queries: How do I help a choking child?

response.immediate_action: If the child is coughing forcefully, encourage them to cough. If they cannot cough, speak, or breathe, begin help.
response.context: For a conscious choking child (over 1 year old).

steps.instruction: Kneel behind the child and wrap your arms around their waist.
Make a fist with one hand. Place the thumb side of your fist against the child's abdomen, just above the navel but below the ribcage.
Grasp your fist with your other hand and perform quick, upward thrusts.

response.additional_notes: Continue thrusts until the object is dislodged or the child becomes unconscious.

warnings: Use less force than with an adult.

user_queries: How do I help a choking baby?

response.immediate_action: If the infant cannot cough, cry, or breathe, begin help immediately.
response.context: For a conscious choking infant (under 1 year old).

steps.instruction: Sit down and place the infant face down along your forearm, supported by your thigh. Keep the head lower than the chest.
Give up to 5 back blows between the shoulder blades with the heel of your hand.
If the object is not dislodged, turn the infant face up on your thigh, still keeping the head low.
Give up to 5 chest thrusts using two fingers on the center of the chest, just below the nipple line.

response.additional_notes: Alternate between 5 back blows and 5 chest thrusts until the object is dislodged or the infant becomes unconscious.

warnings: Never perform abdominal thrusts (Heimlich) on an infant.

user_queries: Help, I got a bad cut!

response.immediate_action: Put on disposable gloves if available to protect yourself from bloodborne pathogens.
response.context: For controlling severe bleeding from a wound.

steps.instruction: Have the person lie down and elevate the wounded area above the level of the heart, if possible.
Apply direct pressure to the wound with a sterile gauze pad, clean cloth, or your hand if nothing else is available.
If blood soaks through the cloth, do not remove it. Add more layers on top and continue applying pressure.
If bleeding does not stop with direct pressure, apply pressure to the artery supplying the area (arterial pressure point).

response.additional_notes: Once bleeding is controlled, secure the dressing with a bandage.

warnings: Call 911 if bleeding is severe, spurting, or does not stop with direct pressure.
Do not apply a tourniquet unless bleeding is life-threatening and cannot be controlled by other means.

user_queries: my child touched the hot pan
what to do for a burn

response.immediate_action: Assess the burn. If it is severe (large, deep, on face/hands/genitals), call 911 immediately.

steps.instruction: Cool the burn immediately. Hold it under cool (not cold) running water for at least 20 minutes.
Remove any jewelry or tight clothing from the burned area, but do not remove anything that is stuck to the skin.
Cover the burn loosely with a sterile, non-stick dressing or cling film.

response.additional_notes: Over-the-counter pain relievers can help with pain.

warnings: DO NOT use ice, butter, ointments, or creams on the burn.
DO NOT break any blisters.

response.immediate_action: Stop activity and avoid putting weight on the injured joint.
response.context: Follow the RICE method for the first 48 hours.

steps.instruction: Rest: Avoid using the injured area.
Ice: Apply an ice pack wrapped in a cloth for 20 minutes every 2-3 hours.
Compression: Wrap the area with an elastic bandage to reduce swelling. Do not wrap too tightly.
Elevation: Raise the injured area above the level of the heart as much as possible.

response.additional_notes: See a doctor if you hear a popping sound, cannot bear weight, or have severe pain.

warnings: Do not apply heat in the first 48 hours as it can increase swelling.

user_queries: I think I broke my bone
what to do for a broken bone

response.immediate_action: Call 911 if the injury is to the head, neck, back, hip, or thigh; if the bone has broken through the skin; or if the person is unresponsive.
response.context: The goal is to immobilize the area and prevent further injury until help arrives.

steps.instruction: Tell the person not to move the injured area.
If you must splint the injury, do so without trying to realign the bone. Splint it in the position you found it.
Apply a cold pack wrapped in a cloth to the area to reduce swelling and pain.

response.additional_notes: Keep the person warm and calm while waiting for emergency services.

warnings: DO NOT try to push a protruding bone back into the body.
DO NOT allow the person to eat or drink in case surgery is needed.

user_queries: severe allergic reaction what to do
my friend is having an allergic reaction

response.immediate_action: This is a life-threatening emergency. Call 911 NOW. Use the EpiPen immediately while waiting for help.
response.context: For a severe allergic reaction (anaphylaxis) where the person has been prescribed an EpiPen.

steps.instruction: Grip the EpiPen in your fist with the orange tip (needle end) pointing downward.
With your other hand, pull off the blue safety release.
Swing and firmly push the orange tip against the outer mid-thigh until you hear a loud 'click'. Hold in place for 3 seconds.
Remove the EpiPen and massage the injection area for 10 seconds.

response.additional_notes: The person must still go to the hospital even if they feel better, as a second reaction can occur.

warnings: Do not put your thumb, fingers, or hand over the orange tip.
Inject only into the thigh.

user_queries: Blood from nose what to do

response.context: Most nosebleeds look worse than they are and can be stopped easily.

steps.instruction: Sit up straight and lean forward slightly. Do not lie down or tilt your head back.
Pinch the soft part of your nose (just below the bony bridge) firmly between your thumb and finger.
Breathe through your mouth and hold this pressure for 10-15 minutes without releasing.

response.additional_notes: You can apply a cold compress to the bridge of the nose to help constrict blood vessels.

warnings: Leaning forward prevents blood from flowing down the throat, which can cause nausea or choking.
See a doctor if the nosebleed lasts longer than 20 minutes, results from a serious injury, or occurs frequently.

response.immediate_action: This is a medical emergency. Call 911 immediately.
response.context: Heatstroke is a life-threatening condition where the body's temperature regulation fails.

steps.instruction: Move the person to a cool, shaded area or an air-conditioned room.
Remove unnecessary clothing.
Cool the person rapidly by whatever means available: immerse in cool water, spray with a hose, sponge with cool water, or place cold, wet cloths on their head, neck, armpits, and groin.
Fan air over the person while they are wet to speed cooling.

response.additional_notes: Do not give the person anything to drink if they are confused or unconscious.

warnings: Do not give the person aspirin or acetaminophen to reduce fever.
metadata.source: CDC (Centers for Disease Control and Prevention)

user_queries: someone is very cold and confused
what to do for extreme cold exposure

response.immediate_action: This is a medical emergency. Call 911 immediately.
response.context: Hypothermia occurs when the body loses heat faster than it can produce it, causing a dangerously low body temperature.

steps.instruction: Move the person to a warm room or shelter.
Remove any wet clothing gently.
Warm the center of the body first (chest, neck, head, groin) using an electric blanket or skin-to-skin contact under loose, dry layers of blankets and clothing.
If the person is alert and can swallow, offer warm, sweet non-alcoholic drinks.

response.additional_notes: Handle the person gently, as rough movement can trigger dangerous heart rhythms.

warnings: Do not apply direct heat (hot water, heating pad, heat lamp). Warm the person slowly.
Do not give the person alcohol.
